bestBHT.bht: Jesus addressed Peter alone, instructing him to launch out into the deep, while the whole crew was told to let down their nets for a draught. This act of faith and obedience went beyond the surface, impressing Simon Peter and revealing Jesus' purpose of being a fisher of men. The request to go into deeper waters challenged Simon Peter to trust in Jesus' leading and have greater confidence in Him.

Henry Alford: Launch out is, in the original, singular, as addressed to Peter alone.
Let down is plural, as addressed to the fishermen in the ship collectively.
When they had this done, of the doers, of the act.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: recompense for the use of his boat.
Albert Barnes: Launch, out - Go out with your vessels.
Into the deep - Into the sea; at a distance from the shore.
For a draught - A draught of fish; or let down your nets for the “taking” of fish.
Marvin Vincent: Launch out. Rev., put out. The singular number, addressed to Peter as master of the craft.
Let down [χαλασατε]. The plural, addressed to the whole of the boat's crew.
Metaphorically, to be indulgent, to pardon.
Philip Schaff: Put out into the deep, i.e., the deep water. Luke always uses proper nautical phrases."
Addressed in the singular, to Simon.
Our Lord first makes a slight request of Simon, then after His discourse a greater one, calling for more confidence in Himself.
Archibald T. Robertson: He ceased speaking (aorist middle indicative and present active participle, regular Greek idiom).
The same double compound verb as in verse Luke 5:3, only here second aorist active imperative second person singular.
This purpose was the startling thing that stirred up Simon.
John Gill: Now when he had left speaking."
He said unto Simon, launch out into the deep."
Let down your nets for a draught.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus instructed Peter alone to launch out into the deep, while addressing the whole crew to let down their nets for a draught. Putting aside their exhaustion from a fruitless night of fishing, they obeyed. This act of faith and obedience to Jesus' command went beyond the surface, impressing Simon Peter and revealing Jesus' purpose of not only being an itinerant preacher but also a fisher of men. The request to go into deeper waters challenged Simon Peter to trust in Jesus' leading and have greater confidence in Him.

Jesus instructed Peter alone to launch out into the deep, while addressing the whole crew to let down their nets for a draught. This act of faith and obedience went beyond the surface, impressing Simon Peter and revealing Jesus' purpose of being a fisher of men. The request to go into deeper waters challenged Simon Peter to trust in Jesus' leading and have greater confidence in Him.

Jesus addressed Peter alone, instructing him to launch out into the deep, while the whole crew was told to let down their nets for a draught. This act of faith and obedience went beyond the surface, impressing Simon Peter and revealing Jesus' purpose of being a fisher of men. The request to go into deeper waters challenged Simon Peter to trust in Jesus' leading and have greater confidence in Him.

Jesus addressed Peter alone, instructing him to launch out into the deep, while the whole crew was told to let down their nets for a draught. This act of faith and obedience went beyond the surface, impressing Simon Peter and revealing Jesus' purpose of being a fisher of men. The request to go into deeper waters challenged Simon Peter to trust in Jesus' leading and have greater confidence in Him.

Jesus specifically told Peter, in the singular, to launch out into the deep, while addressing the entire crew, in the plural, to let down their nets for a draught. This act of obedience demonstrated their trust in Jesus and revealed His purpose as the fisher of men. The invitation to go deeper challenged Simon Peter to place greater confidence in Jesus and follow His leading, going beyond their comfort zone to experience His abundant blessings.
